para.paratext: In Tot v. U.S.,[1] the United States Supreme Court established a test which protects a defendant's due process rights by requiring statutory presumptions to be reasonable with a “rational connection” between the proven facts and the presumed fact.

In Leary v. U.S., the court interpreted the rule as requiring invalidation of a statutorily authorized inference “unless it can at least be said with substantial assurance that the presumed fact is more likely than not to flow from the proved fact on which it is made to depend.”[2]

The Georgia Supreme Court further explained that while a rebuttable presumption which has a “rational connection” between what is proven and what is to be inferred does not constitute a denial of due process, “a presumption which cannot be rebutted by any amount of uncontradicted evidence or which precludes any opportunity for the production of contrary evidence is inconsistent with the principles of due process.”[3]

In Sherod v. State,[4] the court applied this rule to a statutory presumption created in O.C.G.A. § 16-8-4, which provided that a person having personal property under his control by virtue of a lease or rental agreement who fails to return the personal property within five days of having received a demand letter is presumed to have knowingly converted the property. Thus, by proving that the demand letter was properly sent and that the property was not returned within five days, the presumption establishes guilt of the crime of theft by conversion of leased property without the prosecution having to prove all elements of the charged offense beyond a reasonable doubt. The court found this was an unconstitutional violation of due process. Likewise, any mandatory presumption that operates in this manner in a criminal case is unconstitutional.[5]

The United State Supreme Court has considered other Georgia presumptions under the rational connection test. For example, Georgia's presumption of knowledge by one possessing premises on which a moonshine still was located did not violate due process.[6] However, Georgia's presumptions of fraud on the insolvency of a bank[7] and negligence of a railroad[8] were invalid.

Georgia courts have also reviewed the validity of statutory presumptions. The Georgia Supreme Court sustained a presumption of intent to defraud based on the execution of a check with insufficient funds on deposit[9] and a failure to pay labor and material costs after receiving a loan to improve realty.[10]
In Flint River Mills v. Henry,[11] the court found valid the conclusive presumption of dependency of stepchildren in workers' compensation awards created by O.C.G.A. § 34-9-13.

In Hall v. State,[12] the court found valid two presumptions under O.C.G.A. § 16-9-20 in a bad check case under the “rational connection” test, but found a presumption that notice had been received after mailing, “whether such notice shall be returned undelivered or not” to be so arbitrary as to violate due process.
The Georgia Court of Appeals held that a city ordinance stating that possession of intoxicating liquor within the city would raise a presumption of purchase within the city violated due process.[13]

However, in Burdett v. State,[14] the court upheld the head-of-household presumption under O.C.G.A. § 19-3-8, which created a presumption that any contraband found in a home was in fact possessed by the husband head of the household. However, when the Georgia Supreme Court considered the same question in Knighton v. State,[15] it held that the statutory presumption created by the head-of-the-household statute was unconstitutional because the fact that a statute has declared the husband to be the head of the household does not render it “more likely than not” that he is the possessor of contraband found therein.[16]

Later, in Mobley v. State,[17] the Georgia Court of Appeals cautioned that “notwithstanding the unconstitutionality of a rebuttable presumption of possession as against a husband, there is a viable rebuttable presumption of possession, without regard to gender or marital status, as against the owner or lessee of the premises where the contraband is found.”[18]
See also Usery v. Turner Elkhorn Mining Co., 428 U.S. 1, 96 S. Ct. 2882, 49 L. Ed. 2d 752, 1 Fed. R. Evid. Serv. 243 (1976).

Mobley v. State, 190 Ga. App. 771, 772, 380 S.E.2d 290 (1989). The Court in Mobley, recited an example of a rebuttable presumption, concerning the possession of contraband, which does pass constitutional muster:

Ladies and gentlemen of the jury, I charge you that if you find that a person owns or is the lessee of a house or premises, you will be permitted, but not required, to presume that such person is in possession of the entire premises and all the property thereon or therein. However, this is a rebuttable presumption and may be overcome by evidence in the case that others had access to the premises. Whether or not this presumption is drawn from proof that a person is the owner or lessee of a house or premises, and whether or not the presumption once it is drawn has been overcome by proof that others had access to the premises, are questions for the jury alone. I further charge you, in that connection, that if you find that the house or premises were used by others, with the defendant, such evidence would not alone authorize a conviction, but such a fact, if it is a fact, should be considered by the jury together with all the evidence in the case in passing upon the guilt or innocence of the defendant.
See Knighton v. State, 248 Ga. 199, 200, 282 S.E.2d 102 (1981).
